headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're going to get started out now. My name is Scott Satterfield. I'm with S&P Global Market Intelligence based in New York. And we're excited to have everyone here today. It's a nice crowd, more than we expected, so that's a great thing.So today, we're
componenttext:
We're going to get started out now. My name is Scott Satterfield. I'm with S&P Global Market Intelligence based in New York. And we're excited to have everyone here today. It's a nice crowd, more than we expected, so that's a great thing.
So today, we're excited to have everyone here in the panelist and, of course, to talk -- and we're going to focus on the new drivers of change in credit markets. That's going to be -- that's the basis for today, of course. And as we think about what's going on and what's going on in credit these days and sort of erosion in credit standards, chasing yields, Fed, they're trying to decide if they're going to raise rates or not, Brexit, different things going on. We're really excited to hear what the panels are going to talk about today and what the impact is going to be. And of course, who knows what the presidential election is going to bear on us and -- but it's over in 3 weeks. Everyone said, "Hallelujah [indiscernible], yes.
So what will be the topics today? So the things we're going to cover. So transformative trends and credit risks analysis and modeling, the new financial technology landscape and what is the potential impact on big data and artificial intelligence.
So about 3 years ago, S&P Global started working with Ed to help us try to -- to help us inform our products, our clients and provide a bigger impact across the board. So it's been this really great partnership with us, and we're really appreciative of Ed to help us go through that process. So -- and in a bag, Ed -- so Ed's going to kick off in just a second. But there's -- we're talking about the beginning of this quantitative -- or modern history of quantitative modeling and Ed really -- there's no real distinctive date that occurred. But of course, Ed's 1968 Altman Z-score is probably the genesis of a lot of it. So we're -- it's a big tribute to Ed.
So finally, let me talk to you just a little bit about it. So Ed's going to come up and talk about where we are in the credit cycle. And is there a bubble building in the corporate and sovereign credits? I think Ed's resume speaks for itself. And looking through his bio is like a Tolstoy novel today. But -- and just a few things about him. So Ed is the -- and some of this stuff is on the board, too. So Ed is the Max Heine professor of Finance Emeritus at Stern in New York City -- New York University. He is the Director of Research and Credit and Debt Markets at NYU-Salomon Center in Study of Financial Institutions. Prior to serving in his present position, Ed was the Chair at the Stern School's MBA Program for 12 years. He is an international -- he has an international reputation. He's an expert for corporate bankruptcy, high yield bonds, distressed debt, credit risk and analysis. In 2005, Ed was named the 100 Most Influential People in Finance by Treasury & Risk Magazine. 
So let's get out of here and let him do his thing. Thank you, all.

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for coming out. I'm still not sure why you come out early in the morning. I'm probably up at this hour and -- but the fact that you came from probably far away and -- is really very nice and we appreciate i
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for coming out. I'm still not sure why you come out early in the morning. I'm probably up at this hour and -- but the fact that you came from probably far away and -- is really very nice and we appreciate it very much. As Scott mentioned, I've been working with what used to be called Capital IQ. And I think it's probably still known as that to most of you. They have a new name, Global Market Intelligence. And I'm delighted to work, particularly with their risk solutions group -- risk group. I loved risks for a long time. And I'm not too happy these days. I haven't seen enough risk out there and -- so I'll see if you're going to be commenting on that. But seriously, it's been a turbulent period for me to talk about this subject.
Usually, when I come to the West Coast about this time, the Giants are in the World Series, and so that's not on this year. And since I grew up in New York City a long time ago and the Giants were back East, along with the Yankees, and I used to live in that little area between the 2 baseball fields. I feel a great affinity to the West Coast. I did my doctorate here. I met my wife and we were married out here in California. And now we're back in New York, but coming out here is always very special. On this trip, actually, I've been on an election tour in Asia and I can talk a little bit, perhaps later on, about what's going on there and what's going on Asia, real impact on the markets and vice versa. And so it's very interesting to get a different perspective as you travel and learn about what the local folks are thinking about us and vice versa, including Tokyo and Seoul for a big conference there.
And this subject of -- well, it's not on the slide. This topic about where we are in the credit cycle, and is there a bubble building? I've been thinking about this and speaking about it and writing about it for about a year, a little over 1.5 year now. I remember giving a speech in late January or early February 2015 at the local New York Turnaround Management Association group, which I spent a lot of time with back in New York, about where we were in the credit cycle then, so take us back 1.5 years. And if you don't mind, I'll continue the baseball metaphor. I usually have to when I'm speaking, either in the U.S. And it was really wonderful when I'm speaking in Tokyo and Seoul because they're baseball crazy there as well. So you don't have to explain the fact that a baseball game lasts typically 9 innings. And back 1.5 year -- a little over 1.5 years ago, we were talking about the benign credit cycle and I'll define what I mean by benign cycle, even though the general name will probably be pretty obvious to most of you. The benign credit cycle was in the seventh inning. A typical ballgame would last 9 innings. In other words, it was mostly over. And that we were possibly going to be moving into a stress cycle, and I'll define what I mean by a stress cycle in a few minutes, probably in a year to 18 months. And so that was back 1.5 years ago. And then I updated that and wrote some papers on the subject of the credit cycle and how it compares this time with 2006 and 2007 prior to the great financial crisis, and that we were in the ninth inning last January, 1 year after that and about 8 months ago. And I thought I was so smart, really. I said, "Wow, stuck in the dugout, ninth inning, the game is almost over." And that was January, February of this year, so you may remember what happened then. I'll show you in gory detail what happened then. I thought I'm really so smart. But I know that in baseball, if the score is tied at the end of 9 innings, the game is not over and we go into extra innings. And I think that's where we are today. We are in extra, extra innings of the credit cycle. And the umpire in this game, and the one that's going to determine -- help determine how long we're going to be in those extra innings, is -- are the 4 major central banks of the world. Certainly, the Fed, and you'd been following the Fed's activities as most people have for a long time, we've never seen the Fed being so aggressive, interventionist and involved in capital market activity, even though they use the rubric [ph] jobs and that's well -- and that's part of the double deal. But it's not only them. It's European Central Bank, the Bank of Japan, and of course, the Bank of China. The 4 major banks of the world decided independently supposedly, but they certainly were looking what each other were doing in February of this year that they were not going to, at least on their watch, permit another stress cycle to start. They weren't thinking about credit markets as much as we were. They were talking, of course, about growth and inflation, and that was what they were thinking about. And they started pouring, again, enormous amounts of liquidity into the system, which has continued to this day.
Continuing the baseball metaphor for a few minutes further. I was in my dentist's chair, as I unfortunately am quite frequently. I get a lot of information from 2 sources, my dentist and taxi drivers. And I told my dentist, who's a great guy, Pankaj Singh is his name, about the baseball metaphor. And in fact we're extra innings and he said, "Oh, that's great, yes, really." I really dig that. Well, what happens in extra innings is you have your best relief pitchers first, right? They come in, in the eighth, ninth, 10th inning. And then you dig down a little deeper into the barrel to get another relief pitcher and the like and except when -- I mean, the New York Yankees, this is really a pitiful year, when you think of it. We have 3 of the best relief pitchers in the world. And now 2 of them are making their mark in the World Series now, thank goodness for the teams that they're with. And it's, of course, Chicago and Cleveland. And anyway, the relief pitchers come in and after a while, you use up your good relief pitchers, And so isn't it likely that the game's going to be over pretty soon because batters are finally going to score some runs. And every time we've seem to be ready to score some runs and the game is over, something happens to change things. And the benign cycle, and I'm going to show you that what I mean now, is still with us. And so I'd have about a lot of egg on my face thinking that the benign cycle is going to be over shortly after January, February this year. And here we are in September, October and it is still with us.
So let's talk about what we mean by the benign cycle. I look at the credit cycle using 4 metrics, and I'm sure others metrics are possible. Default rates, recovery rates given default and the 2 together, of course, are known as loss given default or LGD; yields and spreads and liquidity, so the 4 metrics. It's very clear if you have low default rates, higher recovery rates, if there are defaults, low interest rates and low spreads compared to what we used to call the risk-free rate. Now we call it the benchmark rate, the treasury rate. And if high liquidity, you're in a benign cycle. And so 1.5 years ago, we were clearly in a benign cycle. Default rates were low. Recovery rates were very high, and I'll explain what I mean by recovery rates. Spreads were average or slightly below average. And there was tons of liquidity, new issue markets. And by the way, I'm going to use as my benchmark in the credit cycle to a market that I've been following since 1982 called the high-yield junk bond market. And the reason why is that first of all, it's very selfish on my part, I've done a lot of data. And data is really important anytime we do research. And we got into this market really early when Morgan Stanley asked me to do a internal study on whether they should get involved in this market back in 1982. And the rest is history. And also high-yield markets now are incredibly important because most people think that's the only game in town to get some yield. And that, of course, has been driving the markets dramatically in 2016. It's with these very, very low interest rates that surround us. So default rates, recovery rates, yields and liquidity. Those are the 4 metrics that we're going to talk about. I'm also going to, if you permit me, try to relate what's going on today to what happened in 2007. Of course, that was just before the crisis. And I remember in 2007, I was giving a speech for a large French bank in Montréal, North American division of this international bank. And I was painting a really bleak picture about the credit cycle and where we were headed. And I predicted that we will go into a bad stress cycle. But my focus was on the corporate market. If you recall, as we all know what happened, the big problems were in the mortgage-backed securities, so prime markets. And then the corporate markets followed in a state of bankruptcies and defaults late '08 and '09 is now quite clear in history. So I was giving the speech and at the end of the speech, the President of the bank pulled me aside and said, "You know Prof. Altman, that was a very convincing argument that you just made about the credit cycle ending in terms of the benign and that we're going into a more stress period. If I follow what you say, I should be reducing my exposure, hedging my risk and maybe even going short credit primarily through the CDS market." I said, "Well, that's very flattering if you think that what we were saying is likely to happen." He said, "Yes, yes, but I don't have the courage to do it." I said, "What I don't understand, if you think it's the right strategy, why do you need to be courageous?" He said, "Well, you don't understand my job." I said, "Yes, that's probably right. That's why you're a bank president and I'm a college professor." And he said, "No, no. I'm serious. You don't understand my job." I said, "Well, could you explain?" He said, "Listen, if you're right and the credit markets change, and we have taken the appropriate actions in anticipation of that by hedging or even going short, I'm going to be a hero and get a big bonus. But if you're wrong and I take your advice, and the train keeps speeding down the track, and liquidity stays really high and the credit markets stay booming, I'm going to lose my job." I said, "Oh I didn't know that, but I think you're probably right " And I think there were a lot of people at those -- at that time in '07 who felt the same way, that the markets were getting really frothy. Anything that walked through the door get financed. High-yield returns were very high. Risky debt was booming. And so he didn't hedge, and he didn't cover his positions that much. And things changed very dramatically as we all know starting in '08, and I'll show you the curves at that point.
So how different is today than '07? That's I think one of the things we want to explore. And of course, there's that famous book and that famous argument, this time it's different. And it is. There's no question. It's different now than it was in '07. And the question is, how long will that difference permeate the markets? And it's primarily the activities of the central banks who really got wrong the last time. The regulators deserve as much discredit as the bankers and all the people who were being sued. Although you don't sue a regulator and you just, of course, hopefully change the people and maybe you change the strategy, which is what we're seeing now becoming much more aggressive earlier.
So let's talk about these 4 metrics. And then I want you to use some ancient models that I built, some of them not so ancient, but certainly going back 50 years now. 50 is a magic number for me, by the way, I've been 50 years in NYU. 50 years ago, I built the Z model. And 50 years ago, I got married. So it's very easy to remember how long I've been married. I just think about the model. But it's a bankrupt model. Anyway, 50 years ago, we built this model. I want to try to bring that into play as well in our discussion. 
So of course, we're talking about investment grade, noninvestment grade. And we're going to spend the most time on the high-yield junk bond market, which, by the way, today, is about USD 1.7 trillion, about 1/2 of the investment grade market in corporate debt, but most of the investment grade market and corporate debt is in financial institutions. If we take out financials, they are more industrial, high-yield and they are all industrial high-grade. And so we're going to focus on that market. And just to give you some numbers, about $4.3 trillion investment grade, $1.65 trillion high-yield, total about USD 6 trillion straight debt, not counting corporate, not counting mortgage backs and other types of debt that are involved. And you can see the breakdown of financials and industrials and utilities.
Here's the growth of the high-yield market. When I got involved back in the early '80s, the market was tiny, essential, all fallen angels. And now about 80% of the market are in original issue junk. And as cost is one area to look at as to liquidity. I mean, we all can know what liquidity is, but to actually define it and to measure it is very tricky and very difficult. And the academics have been struggling with the term liquidity for a long, long time. And nobody has it yet. We all know when it's highly liquid or illiquid. But we don't really know how -- the right metric to look at. I personally like to look at the ability of highly risky companies to refinance, to get liquidity in a period. If they have difficult times when illiquid and they have a lot of easy times as they have lately, it's highly liquid. So we're at $1.6 trillion.
And default rates, let's see where we are. Default rates, of course, are defined as the -- either bankrupt, missed interest payment or distressed exchanges relative to the size of the market. This graph, and you can see this one perhaps a little bit more clearly, shows you the default rate on high-yield bonds going back to the late '80s. And we've had 3 periods of stress cycle. And notice that in between the default rates being 10% or more, we've got 3 of them, 1991, '01 and '02. And again in 2009, with 3 times. And in between, we have the benign cycles. And actually, if you went back to the 1970s, the yellow bars here represent the recession periods in the United States. And here are the 3 peaks again on the default rates. And here are your benign cycles, 1, 2, 3, 4. And we're in the fifth. We were in the fifth for sure until the beginning of this year and that's why in the default rate, one of the metrics, was below the historic average of 3.4%. That's the historic average for high-yield bonds.  And so if you look at these cycles, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5,  the length of the benign cycles in the U.S. had been between 4 and 7 years, the longest being 7 in this period and the shortest being 4 in this period. And we are now 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. And at the beginning of this year, we were entering the seventh year of a benign cycle.
But the 4 metrics began to disperse -- oh, I hit that by mistake, sorry about that. What can we do? Press it one more time. So I do it again, I'm okay. It's kind of fun. Okay, good. All right. So here we are, and for the first time since 2009, the default rate on high-yield bonds is now higher than the historic average for the last 12 months. We are now at about 4.5% last 12 months' default rates. Year-to-date, we are at 3.64%, that's was as of the 23rd of September. My assistant just wrote to me yesterday, said we're about 3.75% as of yesterday. So 3.75% last -- is the year-to-date default rate on high-yield bonds. And about 70% of that is energy, mining and -- energy and mining. So a lot of people are saying this time it's different. If you get rid of energy and mining, the default rate is really pretty low, only 30% of 3.7% is other industries but I learned over the years, you can't throw out the bad industry, there's always in default rates whether it was telecoms back in the early 2000, whether it was autos, chemicals and the industry back in '08, '09 or LDL red defaults back in the late '80s. You always have them but a lot of people are saying this time it's different. And the irony is, that sometimes high default rates engender tremendous recoveries in the market at the same time that the default rates are peaking. And the reason is that the market expected even worse defaults.
So the years 1991, 2009 and this year turned out to be the best years ever to be in risky debt. And yet all those years have relatively high default rates. And the reason is that the markets and people like myself and Standard & Poor's and a few others, I won't even mention their names, forecasts the default rates that sometimes were not right, we're overshoot , so back in 2009 or earlier 2008, we forecasted 2009, we were -- many of the pundits were thinking the default rate would be 15% to 20% of the high-yield market, it turned out only to be 11%. The second-largest ever. And the markets recovered dramatically. Something like that is happening this year. We expected this year, and I can show you the forecast, somewhere between 4.4% Moody's and 6% Fitch and I was in the middle at about 5%, all pretty big increases in the default rate this year. Yes, it has increased. We're at 3.7% year-to-date. My forecast was 5% for this year. I'm probably going to come in a little high. Maybe it'll be 4%, 4.5% depending on a lot of things, including the price of oil for the next 3 months. But we were all forecasting more than the historic average. So the first metric of the 4, the default rate, we can check off as the longer in the benign cycle more than the historic default rate.
Recovery rates. Now many of you know that the CDS market and the high-yield market, and particularly Basel II and Basel III with respect to promotional banks, a lot has to do now only with how many firms default and the hits that the banks take on nonperforming loans, but also on how much the windup recovers. And there are many ways of calculating that recovery rate. I've always been taking the easy route, and that is to measure the price of the security at the time of default, just that. That's the price you could sell the bonds for or loans or the price you pay for if you were a distressed investor. And by the way, the distressed investing industry, which is pretty large, probably about $400 billion under management, has incredible amount of dry powder today. And they are earning because of the new issues to invest in outside of the energy industry are relatively small. And they geared up for a big cycle that we were partially responsible for. But the recovery rate on high-yield bonds is another metric. Historic average corporate bonds recover have a price of about $0.40 to $0.45 on the $1.00 at default. So you get the modeling distressed around $0.80 on the $1, highly distressed at $0.60 on the $1.00. And around $0.40 on the $1.00 is usually the average recovery, at 40% or 45%.
Let's take a look at what's happened lately. Sorry for switching around so much. This is European. Okay, regarding 2014, the default rate was relatively low, 2.11%. Look at the recovery rate, $0.63 on the $1.00. This is corporate bonds that was way above the historic average benign credit cycle, low defaults, high recoveries. And oil and gas was not even that interesting or important then. Then you get to 2015, default rate is creeping up, still below the historic average, recovery rate was $0.34 on the $1.00, much below. But all of it was due to oil and gas and mining. And the average for all it was about the historic average. You could say that things were about normal. But look what's happened in 2016. Through September 23, default rate now above the historic coverage, recovery rate much below the historic average at $0.26. And it doesn't matter if you talk about oil and gas and mining or all of it. It's below the historic coverage.
So the second metric. Recovery rates are moving toward the stress cycle, below the historic average, default rates above the historic coverage. So at the beginning of this year, when we were anticipating these metrics and we've got models to estimate the recovery rate that I can show you as well, given the default rate, we were thinking the benign cycle was in the ninth inning, just about over. And now let's take a look at we said, let's take a look at yields, spreads, risk premiums and liquidity, the other 2 metrics that we look at. By the way, this graph, you may have seen before, was based on a study we did in 2002, published in 2005 with a couple of Italian researchers that I work with from the Bocconi University. And basically, it shows a negative correlation between default rates and recovery rates. So when you got a lot of data on low default rates between 0% and 2% in this quadrant, all of them seemed to have higher recovery rates. 
o the higher the -- the lower the default rate, the higher the recovery. And the opposite out here when you have high default rates and low default rates between 20% and 30%, certainly, about 37% being the highest of any stress period. So if we expect now the default rate to move in this direction, we would expect the recovery rate to move down. So you get the double whammy, right? You get high defaults and low recoveries. So whenever we forecast default rates, as we did this year, we then plug that into the forecast of recovery rate, and basically, it's a supply-demand dimension that determines that. 
So the first 2 metrics -- by the way, here's a lot of data on -- if you're really into defaults and particularly in the oil and gas and mining industry, here's the energy mining Chapter 11 filings since beginning of 2015 when we became interested in the benign cycle again. 41% of all bankruptcies were in energy and mining. And if you look at defaults -- [indiscernible] defaults are different, then bankruptcies, you can default in a lot of ways that you don't go bankrupt. The data is even more impressive. And so far since December of -- sorry, January of '15, 72% in dollars of all defaults are in these energy and mining sector. And one of the reasons why the default rate has begun to reduce is the price of oil has now risen to around $50 a barrel, and it was much higher defaults when it was $0.30, $0.35, $0.40 -- $40 per barrel.
Okay, let's look at spreads, interest rates. Here's where we really have egg on our face because here we were in January and February of this year. Spreads were about 850 over treasuries. Historic average about 5.25. If we go back, this is only a period since I gave that speech in Montréal and the historic average is actually about 5.25. So keep that in mind, 5.25 is a typical spread between high yield and treasuries, all right, and it was 850. So this was another metric that looked like we were going into the stress cycle or in it already. And then the question is, would it go this way or this way? And once before it happened in -- since the great financial crisis, and that was 2011, and this was mainly Europe that was driving it, here at the beginning of this year, remember what was driving spreads?

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: China. China and oil. Those were the 2 things that were driving spreads. So oil has been reduced in terms of current concern. And somehow, China is under the radar and not on the top of the radar screen. But things are not better in China today than they
componenttext:
China. China and oil. Those were the 2 things that were driving spreads. So oil has been reduced in terms of current concern. And somehow, China is under the radar and not on the top of the radar screen. But things are not better in China today than they were in January, February. Things are actually far worse. The trade deficit is worse. So they're under $3 trillion now in terms of reserves. The amount of debt in the system has been building dramatically, even though the authorities are trying to put a clamp on it. But look what's happened to the spreads. We're now at -- this says 519. That was as of the 26th. As of yesterday, the spread between high yield and treasuries, 479 basis points or about 4.8%. Now that's one of the metrics -- or one of the indexes [indiscernible]. If you look at Barclays, it's probably even lower than 4.8%. Historic average, 5.25. The market does not seem to be concerned with defaults going forward. And we thought and we still think they should be. So the fundamentals in terms of credit profile, I'm going to ask you some questions on that, seems to be different than what the market seems to be expecting. Market seems to be expecting lower-than-average default rates, and we seem to -- we're expecting higher than average, but not like it was in '08, '09, unless there's a super catalyst out there that we can point to. 
Just to give you a little historic perspective, back here, it was 2,100 basis points, has an opportunity to adjust its spread over treasuries. And back here when I -- in '07, it was as low as 2.6%, and here we are at 4.8%. So the question is now, how low can it go? Or is it going to start going up again? Most people think that high yield, by the way, is up over 16% this year. So if you've been across-the-board in high yield, you would earn around 16%, and that, of course, is one of the few areas that have done really well. But the stock market in this period is about -- up about 5%. But what we've observed, I don't know if you -- what do you think lately, say since the '08 recession? What do you think the correlation is between stock price behavior, returns and risky debt returns, high yield versus, say, the S&P 500, high, low?

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very high.
componenttext: Very high.

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: High. How high? What has been -- well, let's go back a second. What has it been for the last 40 years, 30 years? Not so high, by 0.4. Last 6 years, 7 years? 0.8, cost of 0.8. And there was an article in the Wall Street Journal, I don't know if that's good
componenttext:
High. How high? What has been -- well, let's go back a second. What has it been for the last 40 years, 30 years? Not so high, by 0.4. Last 6 years, 7 years? 0.8, cost of 0.8. And there was an article in the Wall Street Journal, I don't know if that's good or bad, but there was an article in the journal recently, last week I think it was, or maybe it was only this week -- or no, it was in The Sunday Times, in the mutual fund ETF section, about the fact that for the first time, that when a stock -- the correlation between the stock market and the government bond rate has been positive. Usually, that's a -- this gray hedge [ph], you go back and forth, displays the high, that the two are moving together for the first time in a long, long time. So when the stock market goes down, the bond market goes down. And, of course, a lot of people now are concerned with the increase in interest rates going forward, and the long-term rates have come up a little bit. So there are some signs of stress in the system but not if you look at the yield spread on high-yield debt versus treasury. We're at a low rate. So the question is, are we going to go up or down? I don't know if I'm hitting that or not, but I will touch the usual button. Okay, let's move on. I'm going to skip all of this. This is the B- or lower. 
Default rate forecast, I'm going to only highlight something called mortality rates. No, I don't want to even highlight that until I get to another section. I'll come back to this. And I'm going to skip over this in the interest of time. Incidentally, if you look at forecasts, the beginning of this year, we were forecasting about a 5% based on 3 models that we have: mortality rate, yield spread and distressed ratio. If you put -- plug in two of the market measures, how much the market is requiring as a risk premium and something called a distressed ratio. In 1990, I got a commission from a West Coast firm. How many of you remember, if I recall, the Foothill Group ? Any of you? A few of you. Okay. Are they part of Wells Fargo now? Okay, so it was their original identity. And the Foothill Group asked me to do a white paper on distressed debt, which is available from someone now. I have it, certainly. I don't know if [indiscernible] to get it. And so we had to define what is distressed? What is a distressed security? So our metric, and now it's been picked up by just about every investment bank and rating agency, our bond is selling at more than 1,000-over treasuries. So if it's selling at more than 1,000 basis points or 10% above treasuries, so today, it would be about 11.7%, the definition is that, that bond is distressed. So we use that as a metric for forecasting default rates, and you can see that by looking at this regression. Here's your distressed ratio, and it varies between 1% and 2%. And it was as high as 82% back in 2008 when everything was distressed just about. And look at that nice correlation. This is the distressed ratio here and the default rate 1 year later. So the market is kind of predicting how many firms would default. And if you plug in to this very simple regression, the distressed ratio, which is now down to only 13%, 13% of high yield on distressed. At the beginning of 2015, when we first looked about it, it was 25%. You plug that in and you get a forecast of only 2.7%, where it was 4.4% at the beginning of the year. So we use that as one of the metrics.
Okay. Let me ask you a question now. You've heard enough about me, and now I will get some insights from you. What do you think is the credit profile of a typical U.S. corporate today? And I'm emphasizing high yield, but we can talk about investment grade as well. But let's talk -- let's restrict it to typical high-yield bond issuer. Is it today more or less risky, higher probability of default or lower probability of default or the same as it was in 2007? More risky, less risky or about the same as it was in '07? How many of you think today's typical corporate credit profile is less risky, less risky than it was in '07? No one? I've never had an audience. Might be all asleep. Okay, think about it.

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. 2 nice folks said less risky. Anyone else? More risky. A lot of barons out other. [indiscernible]. And about the same? Okay. It looks like about the same or more risky are pretty much equal. So I asked myself that question. And I didn't know the ans
componenttext:
Okay. 2 nice folks said less risky. Anyone else? More risky. A lot of barons out other. [indiscernible]. And about the same? Okay. It looks like about the same or more risky are pretty much equal. So I asked myself that question. And I didn't know the answer, for sure, but I read about a lot of cash on the balance sheet, relatively good profits until recently. And I started asking this question in 2014, and I'm still asking it. And as we speak today, my assistant is finishing the 2015 year-end data analysis and should have had it done by now. 
Comparative health of high-yield firms '07 versus 2012. And not surprising to you, we use the Z-score as a metric. We built this model 100 years ago, as you know, and you're supposed to laugh. It was a long time ago when we built it. That was 50 years ago, and, of course, things have changed. But this is the original model, if you remember, 5 variables. And if you take the CFA exam, you have to study this. I just gave a couple of talks in Asia to the CFA, and I wasn't very popular because all these folks had to learn the model. They were very polite and they let me finish. So we have 5 variables representing usual fundamentals. Now we're going to talk about in the panel discussion big data, new drivers. This is old data, old drivers, right? This is the fundamental model that simply looked at financial statements, balance sheet, income statement data. And for the first time, we threw in back in 1966, published in '68, the market value of equity relative to the book value of liabilities as a metric, credit metric. Since then, you, of course, have the structural models, the KMV model, et cetera, that center our market value on volatility. We were the first to emphasize market value of equity, but we weren't the first and we didn't think about volatility then, which, of course, is very important.
So if you then -- and we have a second-generation model called Z double prime, which is really better for non-manufacturers and emerging market credits. This one yield book values, so we can now emphasize a risk metric for private firms like leverage buyouts as well as others. So we have these 2 models and we looked at data. And one thing we can do is look at the bond rating equivalents of the Z-score. So here's a very interesting statistic, where all of you have historical-based interest in financial data. When we built the original Z model in 1968, any firm with an overall score of below 1.8, if you added up the -- all the variables and weightings, was in the distressed zone, and 100% of them went bankrupt in our little laboratory. And if the score was above 3, no one went bankrupt at least within 2 years.
Look at how things have changed since 1968. The average B-rated company, which is the dominant junk bond, there are more Bs out there than any other bond, and second only to BBBs in terms of all credit ratings. So Bs are really out there, and the question is, is a B, is a B, is a B? I think William Shakespeare said that back in the -- a long time ago. And the average Z-score, 1.66. In other words, if you look at the old model and the old cutoff scores, the average B-rated company is in the distressed zone and a high percentage default. Well, guess what is the default rate of a newly issued B-rated bond over the last 40 years within, say, 5 years? What percentage of Bs default within 5 years? Any guesses?

componenttextpreview: 50. If I said CCCs, you would have been right. It's not that bad, but it's about -- let me show you the results, had it before, damn it. I want to go back to what areas. The mortality rate, this is like an actuarial approach to looking at default rates, o
componenttext:
50. If I said CCCs, you would have been right. It's not that bad, but it's about -- let me show you the results, had it before, damn it. I want to go back to what areas. The mortality rate, this is like an actuarial approach to looking at default rates, of a B for 5 years is around 28%. So only 28% default by the fifth year, 72% don't, for a B, and yet the average is in the old distressed zone. So don't use those zones anymore, for those of you who still look at Z-scores. And incidentally, I'm told by at least Bloomberg and I'm waiting now for firms like Capital IQ and BlackRock and others who have great data on Z-scores. Who uses Z-scores? Is it the debt guys, the equity ladies? Who's using them? And it turns out Bloomberg tells me that Z-scores get about 5,000 hits a day. And the majority are equity investors, not debt investors, which surprised me. I was expecting the opposite. But with respect to debt, we can get a bond rating equivalent from a score and then plug in some sort of mapping historical default rates but done from a actuarial standpoint rather than a static pool or whatever the Moody's call this. We all look at this cumulative default rates, 28% for Bs and 47% CCCs. Let's get back to that. 
And now let's answer the question, Z-scores versus '07 versus 2014, and here are the results. Here are the number of firms we looked at, and now we're doing it for 2015. And the numbers are increasing. So for Z, we're probably well over 600 companies, and the Z double prime is probably close to 1,000. If you look at the median Z-score in '07, it was 1.81, just about at the threshold of the old distressed zone, and it's 1.8 in 2013. So those of you who voted -- I was out of time. I am out of time. Voted for no change between the average risk profile of '07 versus today, or this is '14 anyway, you would have been correct.
So is that good news or bad news? We're just as risky as '07, at least in terms of Z-scores.

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's bad news, at least if there's any relationship between credit profiles today and default rates. Now you could argue this time is different, and maybe the panel will have some comments on that. I know you've got to look at that, but here's a
componenttext:
I think that's bad news, at least if there's any relationship between credit profiles today and default rates. Now you could argue this time is different, and maybe the panel will have some comments on that. I know you've got to look at that, but here's an objective, there's no emotion in the score. But there's also no role of the Fed in the score. So you got to say that things may not be as much.
Let me conclude by talking about the last metric, and that is liquidity. So let me skip all of these other metrics. These are new issue of data. The blue lines represent new issue high-yield bond data in the U.S. and Europe, and notice how much the new issues escalated in '11, '12, '13, '14 and '15? This is the first half of this year, $98 billion in the U.S. We only have through the -- I should have September when I get back. So if $98 billion was the first half of the year, double that for the year, just by extrapolating, it's about $200 billion new issues. That's a little less than what it was in '15, definitely less than here, still pretty frothy market. Maybe it's going to be higher. Is Sprint noninvestment grade? I think they came out with a big issue recently. So that would add to this quite a bit. Anyway, the new issue market died off for a while, has come back. There was an article about bank lending. For the first time, everyone's surprised at this, bank lending to risky companies, for the first time, dropped in the third quarter of this year. If that's an anomaly, I don't know, but it was a surprise to a lot of people because the bond markets are a little lower than they were. Liquidity seems to be coming a little less so, but maybe everybody who's topped the markets for the low interest rates has done so. I mean, it's very little remaining interest.
When I was a graduate student at UCLA back in the '60s, 1960s, there was this theory called a trade-off theory between debt and equity and bankruptcy costs versus tax benefits. And the idea was there's an optimal capital structure to companies, and companies do move to that outboom [ph], but they go above or below it at times to take advantage of market conditions. And so we observed Times, a lot more debt being issued in low interest rate periods. Well, we've been in a low interest rate period now for 5, 6 years, and we've had companies keep coming in to the market, raising debt, high liquidity. So the leverage ratios are way above historic averages. Imagine certainly in book value terms, market value terms is not as much but it's definitely above. The question is, can you go back? The old theory was, you can always go back where the correlations weren't that high between debt and equity, but now they're very high. And the question is, can you go back so easily when all of a sudden, the stock market goes into decline and so does the bond market? So my guess is capital structure theory needs to be rethought a little bit in terms of this debt versus equity. That's a sideline.
Liquidity. This shows CCC new issuance, which is one of my metrics. The highest year ever was '07, 37% of high-yield bonds were CCCs. You know how ugly CCCs are? They are really ugly. Almost half default by the fifth year, running every 2, and yet in the last 5 to 6 years, the market seems to have said, "Okay, I'll get out before the CCCs hit the fan or the yield risk return tradeoff is favorable even at the CCC level." I'm not convinced and we've got now 10% to 20% of the market as CCCs. A lot of them CCCs, a lot of them are going to fail. The question is, have we kicked the can down the road enough so that it won't happen in the next 12 months? Perhaps, that's the case.
Final metric I want to talk about is the private equity industry. I know we have some private equity folks here, and, of course, the industry is alive and well throughout the world, tremendous number of private equity, LBO deals, especially in this low interest rate market. Let's take a look at some metrics in that -- from that industry. I'm going to skip over this and go through the last one.
Purchase price multiples. This is the average price or median price paid per dollar of cash flow. The highest year in a long, long time was '07, right before the crisis. Public to private was about 10x. This data is coming from S&P Capital IQ. So -- which is where I get a lot of my data these days, and I think it's the best data out there but I'm biased. And they're paying for this breakfast, so -- it was a good breakfast. So 9.9x was high, and then it dropped, of course, in the crisis but not as much as you would have thought. And then 2015, the highest year ever, 11x for primary buyouts. And secondary buyouts, all others, was about 10.2. And 2016 is coming in at a little lower, 10.5x by mid-year for public to private. Both higher than 9.9. So definitely showing a frothy market. You could argue, however, that the debt-to-EBITDA ratio is not as high, 5.5x in the U.S. versus 6.6 in '07 but still quite frothy. And so anytime you get 5.5 to 6x, you're getting into the CCC range, you're getting into very risky range, LBOs.
Now we've done the studying, we haven't published it yet. So the good news about LBO private equity is, on average, default rates are lower than comparably rated plain vanilla issuance for private equity sponsored LBOs. The bad news is, they're all going to go up when you start paying 10, 11, 12x cash flow and use a lot of debt in doing it. We can discuss that as well.
So the last metric, liquidity seems to be still pretty frothy. Yield spreads are low. 2 of the 4 metrics are saying we are still in the benign cycle. 2 of them, default rates and recovery rates, saying we are beginning in a stress cycle. We're in extra innings. So when will it end? I don't know. What will be the catalyst? Perhaps, we can discuss that in the panel discussion. I'll be part of that. 
Sorry for going so long, and thank you for staying. And hopefully, you'll stay now for a terrific panel put together by Cristiano and the folks at Capital IQ, Global Market Intelligence. And so let's take a break. Panelists, come up here, but don't go far. And by the way, if you need the men's or ladies room, it's about 3 miles down. Thank you very mu

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining us for S&P Global's earnings call. Presenting on this morning's call are Doug Peterson, President and CEO; and Rob MacKay, Interim Chief Financial Officer. This morning, we issued a news release with our third quarter
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining us for S&P Global's earnings call. Presenting on this morning's call are Doug Peterson, President and CEO; and Rob MacKay, Interim Chief Financial Officer. 
This morning, we issued a news release with our third quarter 2016 results. If you need a copy of this release and financial schedules, they can be downloaded at investor.spglobal.com. 
In today's earnings release and during the conference call, we're providing adjusted financial information. This information is provided to enable investors to make meaningful comparisons of the corporation's operation -- operating performance between periods and to view the corporation's business from the same perspective as management's. The earnings release contains exhibits that reconcile the difference between the non-GAAP measures and the comparable financial measures calculated in accordance with U.S. GAAP. 
Before we begin, I need to make certain cautionary remarks about forward-looking statements. Except for historical information, the matters discussed in the teleconference may contain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, including projections, estimates and descriptions of future events. Any such statements are based on current expectations and current economic conditions, and are subject to risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially from results anticipated in these forward-looking statements. In this regard, we direct listeners to the cautionary statements contained in our Form 10-Ks, 10-Qs and other periodic reports filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. 
I would also like to call your attention to European regulation. Any investor who has or expects to obtain ownership of 5% or more of S&P Global should give me a call to better understand the impact of this legislation on the investor and potentially the company. 
We're aware that we do have some media representatives with us on the call. However, this call is intended for investors, and we would ask that questions from the media be directed to Jason Feuchtwanger in our New York office at (212) 438-1247. 
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Doug Peterson.

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you, Chip. Welcome, everyone, to the call. This morning, Rob MacKay, our interim CFO, has joined us to cover the financial portion of our third quarter results, and you're -- you'll hear from him shortly. But let me begin with the hi
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you, Chip. Welcome, everyone, to the call. This morning, Rob MacKay, our interim CFO, has joined us to cover the financial portion of our third quarter results, and you're -- you'll hear from him shortly. 
But let me begin with the highlights. We completed several business divestitures with the sale of J.D. Power, our 2 pricing businesses, SPSE and CMA, and the equity research business. This leaves us with a more focused, interrelated portfolio of market-leading businesses. 2 tuck-in acquisitions were added during the quarter, PIRA Energy Group within Platts and Trucost within S&P Dow Jones Indices. 
Several key management additions were announced. We completed the 3-year $140 million cost-reduction initiative that was announced during our Investor Day in 2014. We demonstrated continued revenue growth and productivity progress, which led to an adjusted profit margin improvement of 320 basis points, with every segment delivering organic revenue growth. 
As a result of our share repurchases, we reduced average diluted shares outstanding by 3% year-over-year. Our bottom line result was excellent with a 17% increase in adjusted diluted EPS over the third quarter last year. 
We delivered year-to-date free cash flow of over $1 billion, and we increased our 2016 adjusted diluted EPS guidance to a range of $5.15 to $5.25, which Rob will cover shortly. 
Before we turn to the results, I want to note 3 new appointees to our management team. Steve Kemps joined us from our Quanta Services as EVP of General Counsel. Martin Fraenkel has been promoted to President, S&P Global Platts. Martin previously led the global editorial team at Platts. And Ewout Steenbergen will join us from Voya Financial as EVP and Chief Financial Officer effective November 14. I'm pleased we avoided any disruptions to our businesses as we put in place an excellent leadership team. 
Now let's take a closer look at the third quarter results. Reported revenue grew 9% and organic revenue, on a constant-currency basis increased 8%. In the third quarter, ForEx reduced revenue by $5 million, yet contributed approximately $8 million to adjusted operating profit and approximately 60 basis points to adjusted operating profit margin. Most of this benefit was realized in the Platts segment, which benefited from a weaker British pound. The company delivered a 320 basis point improvement in adjusted operating profit margin. Together, revenue growth, margin improvement and share repurchases led to a 17% increase in adjusted diluted EPS of $1.43 per share. 
In the third quarter, every division recorded organic top line growth. Profit growth, however, was most pronounced at Ratings and Market Intelligence with adjusted operating profit margin gains of 330 and 480 basis points, respectively. 
Let me turn to the businesses, and I'll start with S&P Global Ratings. Despite initial uncertainty from the Brexit vote, third quarter issuance was strong, particularly nonfinancial global corporates and U.S. public finance market. This resulted in a 9% increase in revenue with a 1% unfavorable impact from ForEx. Adjusted operating profit increased 17% due to strong revenue growth and cost containment, particularly with reduced legal and outside services spending. The adjusted operating margin increased 330 basis points to 51.3%. ForEx had a negligible impact on adjusted operating profit. 
Non-transaction revenue was unchanged with growth in surveillance fees offset by lower Rating Evaluation Services fees. Transaction revenue increased 23% as a result of improved contract terms, growth in debt issuance and a 21% increase in bank loan ratings revenue. 
I also want to note that as we work to reenter the U.S. conduit/fusion CMBS market, there were 13 transactions in the quarter, and we rated 2 of them. 
If we look more closely at the largest markets, third quarter issuance in the U.S. was up 7% with investment grade decreasing 3%, high yields soaring 49%, public finance up 16% and structured finance increasing 11% due to a 44% increase in ABS transactions, driven especially by credit card ABS. 
In Europe, issuance increased 14% with investment grade climbing 42%, driven by large M&A transactions, high yield rising 37% and structured finance decreasing 46%, primarily due to a 59% decline in covered bonds. 
In Asia, issuance more than doubled. However, excluding domestic China issuance, which we do not rate, Asia issuance increased 64%. Investment grade surged 166%. However, excluding domestic China, it increased 67%. Japan was the country with the largest increase due to the Bank of Japan's negative interest rate policy. Finally, structured finance increased 2%. 
2 weeks ago, S&P Global Ratings released its latest global issuance forecast. In the 3 months since the Brexit vote, debt markets have reacted very positively with unexpected levels of new issuance, especially in the nonfinancial corporate financial sectors and international public finance sectors. We now expect global issuance to increase 24% in 2016. This compares to the July forecast issued on the heels of the Brexit vote, which anticipated a decline of approximately 4%. If we remove sovereign issuance from the forecast, however, we anticipate issuance 2016 to increase approximately 10%.  Looking ahead to 2017, we expect an overall issuance increase -- we expect an overall increase in global issuance of 5%, driven by the ECB extending its quantitative easing policies longer than currently anticipated and further growth out of China. Excluding sovereign issuance, we anticipate issuance 2017 to increase 3% to 6%. 
Now let me turn to S&P Global Market Intelligence. In the third quarter, revenue increased 21%, primarily due to the addition of SNL. Excluding SNL, organic revenue growth was 7%. Adjusted operating profit increased 43%, and the adjusted operating margin advanced 480 basis points to 31.4%. This improvement was due to progress on SNL integration synergies, operating leverage from strong organic revenue growth and continued efficiency gains. ForEx had a negligible impact on revenue and adjusted operating profit in the quarter. As we have stated before, in 2016, successful integration of SNL and delivery of synergies is a top priority for the company. We've made tremendous progress as evident in the margin improvement, and remain committed to achieving our integration synergy targets and deliver on our expected return on investment in SNL. 
Let me add a bit more color on third quarter revenue growth in Market Intelligence. In financial data and analytics, S&P Capital IQ Desktop and Enterprise Solutions revenue increased 6% with high single-digit growth in S&P Capital IQ Desktop. In addition, on a comparable basis, which includes revenue prior to our acquisition, SNL revenue increased 12% over the third quarter 2015. SNL and S&P Capital IQ Desktop experienced year-over-year user percentage growth in the low teens and high single digit, respectively. 
Risk services revenue increased 10%, led by double-digit RatingsXpress growth. In the smallest category, Research and Advisory, revenue decreased 8% due to declines in equity research. With the sale of Equity Research, the only remaining asset in this category is Investment Advisory. Therefore, in the future, we'll report Investment Advisory as part of Financial Data and Analytics. 
Now let's turn to S&P Dow Jones Indices. Revenue increased 6%, adjusted operating profit increased 1% and adjusted operating margin declined 320 basis points to 66.2%. This is a sizable decline as the third quarter of 2015 benefited from a sharp increase in exchange-traded derivative volume that did not repeat this quarter. I also want to point out that the adjusted margin this quarter is comparable to the 66% figure we reported last quarter. 
During the third quarter, revenue increased primarily due to mutual funds and ETF license fees and steady data license growth. Operating cost increased to support revenue growth in business initiatives as well as increased cost for purchased data. One notable example is connectivity expenses as we recently started up a third data center to provide additional backup capabilities. 
Often on our earnings calls, I cite new products that we have launched. Last quarter, I highlighted the launch of the JPX/S&P CAPEX & Human Capital Index in Japan. The new ETF that was launched based on this index has turned out to be one of the fastest-growing new ETFs this year. It already has over $700 million in AUM. 
Asset linked fee revenue increased 10% during the quarter. The exchange-traded products industry recorded massive inflows of $126 billion in the third quarter, almost triple the inflows in the second quarter. Of the $126 billion of industry inflows, $58 billion went into U.S. equity products, with S&P Dow Jones Indices capturing about 60% of those inflows. Average ETF AUM associated with our indices increased 15% year-over-year with inflows of 10% and the remainder from market appreciation. The quarter-ending ETF AUM associated with our indices reached a new record of $914 billion. 
Transaction revenue from exchange-traded derivatives decreased, primarily due to a 14% decrease in average daily volume of products based on our indices. The E-mini S&P 500 Futures, CBOE Volatility Index Options and Futures, VIX, and CME Equity Complex Contrast -- Contracts all decreased 10% to 25% compared to the volatile third quarter of 2015. 
Subscription revenue, which consists primarily of data subscriptions in custom indices, increased due to growth in data subscription revenue and the timing of subscription revenue. 
During the quarter, the company launched 161 new indices, and our partners launched 11 new ETFs based on our indices. 
Now onto the S&P Global Platts segment, which included J.D. Power results for July and August. Because this quarter has one less month of J.D. Power revenue than the third quarter of 2015, segment revenue declined 8%. Segment organic revenue, though, increased 4%. Adjusted operating profit increased 4%, reflecting one less month of J.D. Power. And adjusted operating margin increased 170 basis points to 40.9%. Organic revenue increased 4% due to growth in subscriptions, partially offset by decline in Global Trading Services. 
The core subscription business delivered mid-single-digit revenue growth, led by the petroleum sector. The Global Trading Services' double-digit revenue decrease is primarily due to the timing of license fees. Gas and power revenue is flat with modest gains in subscriptions, offset by lower GTS service revenue. Metals, Agriculture and Petrochemicals revenue declined low single digit, primarily due to lower revenue from SGX-listed TSI iron ore contracts. We continue to expect modest growth for the remainder of 2016 as many customers continue to face pressure from low oil prices. 
On the business development front, we're building a world-class capability in energy supply and demand information, the acquisition of PIRA Energy Group and the added capabilities of Commodity Flow and RigData, which we acquired earlier this year. 
PIRA is a leader in the worldwide energy market analysis and a great complement to our existing benchmarks. PIRA offers research and analysis in oil, gas, power, natural gas liquids, biofuels, coal, environmental and agricultural markets. They also provide data tools to help customers analyze prices, supply, demand, trade flows, product balances and refining activity. And I'm pleased that Executive Chairman and Founder of PIRA, Dr. Gary Ross, has joined our team and is already generating new product ideas. 
In addition, Platts worked with CME to launch a new futures contract. Alumina FOB Australia Futures will be a 100-metric ton contract and will be financially settled each month against the daily price index published for Alumina FOB Australia by S&P Global Platts. Alumina is aluminum oxide, a white granular material, a little finer than table salt that's transformed into aluminum metal in the smelting process. This new futures contract is in addition to the 3 existing CME aluminum futures contracts based on Platts' benchmark. 
And finally, Brazil's CETIP. Latin America's largest depository of private fixed income securities and Brazil's largest private asset clearinghouse, is going to make Platts' benchmark prices estimates available as settlement mechanisms for the development of domestic derivative contracts. Historically, Brazil's only hedging tools tend to be similar, but not necessarily matching commodity indices, or they were international rather than domestic contracts. 
Investors are increasingly seeking new insights into environmental, social and governance factors. And both our index and ratings businesses are taking action to address these needs. 
First, our S&P Dow Jones Indices acquired Trucost. Trucost has become a leading brand in ESG information sector. They provide the gold standard carbon and natural capital investment metrics that financial institutions need to assess the risks and opportunities presented by climate change and capitalize on the transition to a low-carbon, resource-efficient economy. The complementary nature of our 2 businesses allow us to combine Trucost's industry-leading environmental impact data with our world-class benchmarking capabilities to develop new ESG solutions. 
Second, Ratings is developing a green bond evaluation tool to provide an analysis and estimate of the environmental impact of projects financed by a bond's proceeds. Our proposed approach would address mitigation, such as reducing negative environmental impact and adaptation to look at resiliency to the impact of climate change. The output of the green bond evaluation would include scores from the categories listed here amalgamated into an overall financial green -- final green bond evaluation. I'm encouraged by the innovative thinking underway in the company to help tackle increased ESG needs of investors. 
Before I conclude, I need to point out a reporting change. Beginning in the fourth quarter, we'll report our results under 3 segments: Ratings, Indices, and Market and Commodities Intelligence. We are doing this to be consistent with how we manage our businesses. 
In summary, we completed sales of J.D. Power, 2 pricing businesses and Equity Research. We had consistent results with all segments delivering organic revenue growth. Bond issuance is robust in the third quarter despite the Brexit vote. Our focus on revenue growth and productivity performance led to continued margin improvement. Integration of SNL is progressing well and remains a top priority in 2016. And our adjusted diluted EPS guidance has increased to a range of $5.15 to $5.25 and includes dilution from the sale of J.D. Power, the pricing businesses and Equity Research. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Rob.

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Doug, and good morning to everybody on the call. This morning, I will recap key financial results, discuss the impact from adjustments to earnings, then I'll update you on the balance sheet, free cash flow and return of capital. Next, I'll disc
componenttext:
Thank you, Doug, and good morning to everybody on the call. This morning, I will recap key financial results, discuss the impact from adjustments to earnings, then I'll update you on the balance sheet, free cash flow and return of capital. Next, I'll discuss the completion of our $140 million productivity program, the financial impact of our recent divestitures and update our 2016 guidance. Before wrapping up, I will explain the new segment reporting that will be effective beginning in the fourth quarter and the data we will provide. 
Let's start with the consolidated third quarter income statement. There are just a couple of items I want to highlight. As you've just heard from Doug, all of our segments delivered top line organic growth. Collectively, that led to an increase in reported revenue of 9% with organic growth on a constant currency basis of 8%. The difference is largely due to the SNL acquisition. Foreign exchange rates reduced revenue by $5 million and had a favorable impact of $8 million on operating profit. Our adjusted operating margin increased 320 basis points. Approximately 60 basis points was due to ForEx. The balance was primarily due to outstanding top line growth and margin improvement at S&P Global Ratings and S&P Global Market Intelligence. 
The adjusted tax rate in the third quarter was 31.3%, an increase of 220 basis points over the third quarter of 2015 due to onetime benefits recorded in the prior period. Share repurchases over the past year have resulted in a 3% decline in average diluted shares outstanding. 
Taken together, top line growth, margin improvement and share count reduction combined to deliver a 17% increase in adjusted diluted earnings per share. 
Now let me turn to adjustments to earnings to help you better assess the underlying performance of the business. Pretax adjustments to earnings totaled to a gain of $732 million in the quarter. The largest item is a gain on the sale of J.D. Power. The next item is a net gain from insurance proceed recoveries. And the last item includes net acquisition and disposition-related costs, primarily related to the sale of our SPSE and CMA pricing businesses to ICE, and J.D. Power to the XIO Group. And as we discussed earlier this year, our adjusted results now exclude deal-related amortization, which totaled $23 million during the quarter. All adjustments are detailed on Exhibit 5 of today's earnings release. 
Now let's turn to the balance sheet. At the end of the quarter, we had $2.4 billion of cash and cash equivalents, of which approximately $1.6 billion was held outside of the United States. We also had $3.6 billion of long-term debt and $400 million of short-term debt. The short-term debt is the value of the 2017 notes that were redeemed in October. One other item that I want to point out is that the cash proceeds from the sale of J.D. Power were recorded in the quarter. However, the tax on the gain will not be paid until later in the fourth quarter. 
Free cash flow during the first 9 months was approximately $1 billion. However, to get a better sense of our underlying cash generation from operations, it is important to exclude the after-tax impact of legal and regulatory settlements and related insurance recoveries. On that basis, free cash flow from the first 9 months was approximately $1.1 billion. 
Now I'll review our return of capital. During the quarter, the company initiated a $750 million accelerated share repurchase plan. This resulted in the repurchase of 5.3 million shares during the quarter. However, the final share count reduction will not be determined until the ASR is completed. In addition, the company paid a dividend of $95 million during the quarter. Year-to-date, the company has returned $1.4 billion to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. 
In March of 2014, we initiated a productivity target of greater than $100 million in cost-reduction initiatives during 2014 to 2016. We subsequently increased the target to $140 million. Today, we are pleased to announce the successful completion of this program. We delivered slightly more than the $140 million in savings. If you look at the chart on the right, you can see that our adjusted operating margin has increased by 900 basis points since 2013. The successful achievement of this $140 million productivity target was a key contributor to this improvement. 
While we are pleased with our recent divestitures, we want to make sure all of you understand the loss of revenue and profitability associated with these transactions. J.D. Power, the SPSE and CMA pricing businesses and Equity Research combines to generate $310 million of revenue, $108 million of pro forma adjusted EBITDA and approximately $0.25 of pro forma adjusted diluted EPS to our 2016 results before they were sold. This equates to approximately $100 million of revenue and $0.08 of adjusted diluted EPS that will be foregone each quarter. The recently announced ASR should help offset some of this dilution. We estimate that the ASR will increase diluted adjusted earnings per share by about $0.10 over the next year. We hope these figures will help you with your modeling of our future results. 
Based upon our strong results year-to-date and the expectation that debt issuance remains strong for the remainder of the year, we are increasing our adjusted EPS guidance to a range of $5.15 to $5.25. We've also made changes to other components of guidance as follows: adjusted unallocated expense is reduced to $135 million due primarily to reduced professional fees. The adjusted operating margin increase over 2015 is now expected to be approximately 200 basis points. This is largely due to the excellent performance in Ratings and Market Intelligence. The adjusted tax rate is increased to approximately 31.5%, primarily due to the timing and size of past years' tax settlements. Free cash flow, excluding the after-tax legal and regulatory settlements and insurance recoveries, is increased to $1.4 billion due to strong financial results. Overall, this guidance reflects our expectation that 2016 will be another strong year for the company. 
The final item I want to discuss is the upcoming change to our reporting segments. Beginning in the fourth quarter, S&P Global Market Intelligence and S&P Global Platts will be included in a new segment called Market and Commodities Intelligence. Both fourth quarter results and full year 2016 results of both businesses will be reported in this new segment. To facilitate analysis in the next few weeks, we'll provide a pro forma schedule with results of this new segment for all quarters of 2015 and 2016 as if it had existed this way. This should help investors model 2017 appropriately. 
With that, let me turn the call back over to Chip for your questions.

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is, when you think about the integration of -- or the consolidation of segments of Platts into Market Intelligence and you consider recent divestitures, does this change the mid-30% margin target discussed on the last call for that segment?
componenttext: First question is, when you think about the integration of -- or the consolidation of segments of Platts into Market Intelligence and you consider recent divestitures, does this change the mid-30% margin target discussed on the last call for that segment?

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ashley. So as we were looking at the sale of J.D. Power and then how we're going to manage the company, it was clear that one of the largest opportunities for the Platts business is in the data and analytics space, where we've made recent acquisit
componenttext: Thanks, Ashley. So as we were looking at the sale of J.D. Power and then how we're going to manage the company, it was clear that one of the largest opportunities for the Platts business is in the data and analytics space, where we've made recent acquisitions and see a lot of opportunity for growth in that area. So by putting these businesses working together between Market Intelligence and having them both report to Mike Chinn, we feel there's opportunities for us there. We do -- we will send out further information in the next couple of weeks about how this segment is going to look when we put these businesses together. But we will be targeting blended margin that's in the high-30s range.

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as you continue to shape the company's portfolio and also execute on SNL integration, can you just talk about the kinds of asset you find attractive on the M&A front? Should we just expect more tuck-ins in ESG or in energy? And just also so
componenttext: Okay. And then as you continue to shape the company's portfolio and also execute on SNL integration, can you just talk about the kinds of asset you find attractive on the M&A front? Should we just expect more tuck-ins in ESG or in energy? And just also some thoughts on how you're thinking about using M&A as a tool to drive growth in the fixed income indexing arena today.

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you should consider that we have a disciplined approach to our capital allocation, which starts with investing in our businesses in organic growth. We are obviously going through our year-end review and our 2017 to 2019 strategic planning process, w
componenttext: Well, you should consider that we have a disciplined approach to our capital allocation, which starts with investing in our businesses in organic growth. We are obviously going through our year-end review and our 2017 to 2019 strategic planning process, where we're evaluating ways that we can invest in the business. So investing in organic growth, which could be expansion of regional areas, of new products, of technology investments, et cetera, is very important for us. Following that, obviously, would be ways that we can accelerate growth or expand into new regions or new capabilities through M&A. Then obviously, finally, come our approach to dividends and share repurchase. But when it comes to your question around M&A, we would be looking at many ideas and many options coming in. Tuck-ins could be attractive for us, but it's something that we would do business by business, opportunity by opportunity, look at them separately as they arise. We have seen, as you know, tuck-in acquisitions have been a way for us to grow our portfolio of products in Platts. It's given us opportunities with different areas and services in Market Intelligence. Last quarter, we had purchased a very small rating agency in Thailand in our S&P Global Ratings area. So we would continue to look selectively at areas, but they need to -- we need to ensure that they also meet our parameters for growth and returns.

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. I didn't understand. Thanks. Yes, so when we look at the areas that we have the largest opportunities in this company, we try to find areas where there are still large needs in the markets or areas that are unfulfilled and there's -- we see tha
componenttext: Yes, okay. I didn't understand. Thanks. Yes, so when we look at the areas that we have the largest opportunities in this company, we try to find areas where there are still large needs in the markets or areas that are unfulfilled and there's -- we see that the customers have maybe an avalanche of data they need to make -- somehow they can make decisions around it. One of the areas that is a very fragmented business and there's high growth that relates to data and analytics on the energy markets -- and SNL has a small energy business and Platts, obviously, has a very large energy business -- and we wanted to accelerate the integration of those 2 businesses, but more importantly take advantage of the expertise that we have in the Market Intelligence data machine and how they can work together with Platts on building out that data analytics business. So this was not something that I really felt we should wait. I felt it wasn't something we should wait for a couple of years for. That we needed to move now. The opportunities are going to start cropping up and we wanted to be positioned to take advantage of them as quickly as possible.

componenttext: Clearly, it took second place after the initial integration. So the #1 priority for 2016 was getting SNL and Market Intelligence integrated. And so this is, if you will, kind of step 2, but the practice come quicker than you might have thought.

componenttext: Okay. All right. And then if I could just ask in the Ratings business. Your subscription growth was flat. Just some color there. I know you had some tough evaluation services comps maybe, but curious on how we should think about modeling that piece of the business.

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The -- that was one of the areas that we had a little bit of a flat growth. It was on the subscription side. Rating Evaluation Service was not growing during the quarter. That was one of the areas, in addition to the -- how we're managing the busines
componenttext: Yes. The -- that was one of the areas that we had a little bit of a flat growth. It was on the subscription side. Rating Evaluation Service was not growing during the quarter. That was one of the areas, in addition to the -- how we're managing the business now, looking at the way that we manage our contracts. So the non-transaction business was flat at $343 million during the quarter. It usually grows around 3% to 4% over time. But as you can see, it was offset by a transaction revenue growth of $55 million from $244 million to $299 million. So there was a very robust growth on the transaction side. But we do continue to value highly this non-transaction side, but the main factor was related to lower Rating Evaluation Services fees.

headline: S&P Global, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
